Issues.Title: Question: Entityframework CRUD with Blazor Server Side
Issues.Body:
I have an existing Client/Server Blazor project, that I have just updated to Blazor 0.5.1. The client side runs quite slow, principally due to the time taken to decode JSON (I raised a couple of issues here to see if MessagePack could be used - it cannot because .Net Standard 2.0 does not support System.Reflection.Emit).

I am keen to attempt a port to Blazor ServerSide, which clearly has substantial performance benefits. I am however using EntityFramework Core and SignalR. My question is where I should locate the EntityFramework code: in the Server or App project? So far I attempted to place it in the App, but cannot install for instance the Microsoft.AspNetCore.App Nuget package because it is incompatible with .Net Standard 2.0. Any thoughts please?

I guess that if I do need to use the Server (and I am happy to try), I will again need a Shared Project. This is not a problem because I already have one of these!

Thanks again to the Blazor team for a stunning product. Like many here I hope that Microsoft commits to it and that it can stop being "experimental"...
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Question: Entityframework CRUD with Blazor Server Side" (#1246)

Issues.Title: Making an await call in layout file's OnInitAsync causes hang/deadlock
Issues.Body:
I'm new to async/await and Blazor so keep that in mind.

If, in my designated layout file (in my case, MainLayout.cshtml), I override the OnInitAsync() method and include inside it the call:

await Task.Delay(1000); // (for example)

..when I run the web application, it will appear to hang, i.e. blank screen in the browser with nothing in the console.  If instead I make the same call in a normal page like Index.cshtml, everything works as expected.

Issues.Title: Add immediate visual effect when server side is rendering to mitigate feeling of latency
Issues.Body:
I would like to have support for adding a immediate visual effect to client side when server side is rendering. It would make UI feel more responsive in high latency situations.

Like adding class to a button when it's clicked and remove that class when server responds.
Having way to add spinners to some div when specific event is triggered would be awesome too. Let's say you click a button to update a grid and you could have spinner top of that grid until server responds.

Edit: I mean new server side render introduced in Blazor 0.5
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add immediate visual effect when server side is rendering to mitigate feeling of latency" (#1241)

Issues.Title: Marshal oninput events as UIChangeEventArgs
Issues.Body:
Blazor does handle the oninput event, but it is marshalled as a regular UIEventArgs. This means that we cannot access the new value of the input element from inside our oninput handler. This changes the type of `oninput` events to `UIChangeEventArgs`, so that we can access the new value from our event handler.

Addresses #821
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Marshal oninput events as UIChangeEventArgs" (#1234)

Issues.Title: JSInterop cannot invoke instance methods
Issues.Body:
Right now if you try to invoke an instance method, like `localStorage.setItem`, then you'll receive an rather obscure error like `'setItem' called on an object that does not implement interface Storage.` which means that this line https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/blob/f2232e0699dae28485e07244403385219c1a3832/src/Microsoft.JSInterop/JavaScriptRuntime/src/Microsoft.JSInterop.ts#L160
uses apply to invoke the method on a null reference which isn't supported.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "JSInterop cannot invoke instance methods" (#1232)

Issues.Title: Set @layout null
Issues.Body:
Currently it's not possible to set a component's layout to null
In Razor we used to do something like this:
```
@{
Layout = null
}
```

In Blazor we should be able to do something like this:
`@layout null`

The workaround is to create an EmptyLayout component which is used.
